accessibility_text:
Accessibility

## Accessibility at MGMOA: Ensuring an Inclusive Experience for All

At the Mabee-Gerrer Museum of Art, we are committed to making art accessible to everyone. We strive to create a comfortable and inclusive environment so all guests can fully enjoy our collections and exhibits.

### Social Narrative

We want every visitor to feel comfortable and prepared for their trip to the Mabee-Gerrer Museum of Art. Our[ Social Narrative](http://web.archive.org/web/20260101012858/https://www.mgmoa.org/wp-content/uploads/Mabee-Gerrer-General-Social-Narrative-.pdf) is a helpful guide designed to explain what to expect during your visit, including museum guidelines, available resources and the exciting things you’ll see.

### Parking and Museum Access

  * The museum is one level and does not require the use of elevators or lifts. A curb cut ramp is located on Turner Circle directly in front of the Museum gates. Accessible parking is available on Fr. Blase Schumacher Dr. next to the Sarkey Performing Arts Center.

### Wheelchair Loan

  * Wheelchairs are provided on a first-come, first-served basis.
  * Please note that the number of wheelchairs is limited.
  * Wheelchairs cannot be reserved in advance.

### Sensory Bag Loan

  * **Location:** Sensory bags are available at our main desk.
  * **Contents:** Each sensory bag contains noise‐canceling, child‐sized headphones, fidget tools, and sunglasses.
  * **Availability:** These bags are also offered on a first-come, first-serv...

[Learn More](http://web.archive.org/web/20260105110038/http://www.mgmoa-gallery.com/)

__

__

##### **PLAN YOUR VISIT TO SHAWNEE, OKLAHOMA, TO EXPLORE OVER 8,000 YEARS OF ART AND CULTURE FROM AROUND THE WORLD**

Founded in 1919, the Mabee-Gerrer Museum of Art is one of the oldest museums in the state of Oklahoma. Father Gregory Gerrer, for whom the museum is named, was a Benedictine monk of considerable artistic talent. During Father Gerrer’s travels to Europe, Africa, and South America, he collected objects of artistic and ethological value.

The Museum’s permanent collections include Egyptian, Greek, and Roman objects; art from the Renaissance through the early 20th century; and large holdings of Native American, African, Oceanic, and Eastern cultural artifacts. The Egyptian collection is considered by some to be the finest between Chicago and Los Angeles. In addition, the Museum offers exciting special exhibitions throughout the year.

[ ](http://web.archive.org/web/20260105110038/https://www.mgmoa.org/swan/)
